textContent1: The Court and Tribunal Hearing Information Service provides a publishing platform to enable information provided by HMCTS to be shared, displayed and updated as appropriate. It will enable lists, outcomes, judgments and information to be displayed to court users, consistent with jurisdictional procedures and business rules. The service supports HMCTS’ commitment to open justice and the provision of transparent and consistent court/tribunal information across all jurisdictions.
textContent2: This accessibility statement applies to content published on
textContent3: It is based on an accessibility audit for carried out by the Digital Accessibility Centre (DAC) user/ technical team on 1 March 2022.
textContent4: This website is run by HM Courts and Tribunals. We want as many people as possible to be able to use this website, so we have designed it to be accessible. For example, that means you should be able to:
textContent5: We’ve also made the website text as simple as possible to understand.
textContent6: has advice on making your device easier to use if you have a disability.
textContent7: The summary findings from the accessibility audit reported that users who are cognitively impaired, or use voice activated or keyboard only access, could navigate the site completely independently, with no issues. Users with dyslexia, who were colour blind or had low vision could navigate the site completely independently, but with minor issues.
textContent8: Two high-level accessibility issues have been reported, mostly affecting those using screen readers.
textContent9: The Single Justice Procedure (SJP) Public list, which shows SJP cases and outcomes, is presented in a PDF document that is particularly difficult for screen reader users to navigate.
textContent10: The service sign-in and screens associated with a user needing to reset their password do not follow GDS design principles and are not accessible.

textContent13: We’re always looking to improve the accessibility of this website. If you find any problems not listed on this page or think we’re not meeting accessibility requirements, contact
textContent14: The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) is responsible for enforcing the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (the ‘accessibility regulations’). If you’re not happy with how we respond to your complaint,
textContent15: We provide a text relay service for people who are D/deaf, hearing impaired or have a speech impediment.
textContent16: Our courts and tribunals have audio induction loops, or if you contact us before your visit we can arrange a British Sign Language (BSL) interpreter.
textContent17: HM Courts and Tribunal Service is committed to making its websites accessible, in accordance with the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018.
